title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-) scale validated patient-reported outcome measure provides simple, direct assessment patients’ perceptions treatment efficacy. healthcare delivery increasingly prioritizes patient-centered care, PGI-emerged essential tool urogynecology medical specialties several reasons: Patient-Centered: Directly measures patient’s subjective experience improvement Simplicity: Single item reduces respondent burden Validity: Strong correlation condition-specific quality life measures Versatility: Applicable across diverse treatment modalities conditions Responsiveness: Sensitive clinically meaningful changes Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-) scale presented visual spectrum much better much worse.

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: PGI-scale evolved Clinical Global Impression (CGI) scales originally developed psychiatric research. 2003, Yalcin Bump validated PGI-specifically women urinary incontinence, demonstrating : Strong correlation condition-specific quality life measures Excellent test-retest reliability (kappa = 0.75) High sensitivity treatment effects Strong association objective measures incontinence Since initial validation, PGI-incorporated numerous clinical trials practice guidelines urogynecology. adoption exemplifies shift toward patient-centered outcomes research clinical practice.

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: score_pgii() function processes raw PGI-responses outputs original scores derived binary improvement indicator: Parameters score_pgii() function function returns tibble : * patient identifier column * pgii_score: original PGI-response (1-7 NA) * pgii_improved: Binary indicator (1 = improved [scores 1-3], 0 = improved [scores 4-7]) * pgii_n_valid: (Optional) Count valid responses

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: Let’s start simple example using simulated patient data:
code: # Create sample dataset set.seed(123) # For reproducibility patient_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = paste0("P", 101:120),   treatment_group = rep(c("Surgery", "Conservative"), each = 10),   baseline_score = sample(5:25, 20, replace = TRUE),   pgii_response = c(sample(1:3, 10, replace = TRUE), sample(2:7, 10, replace = TRUE)) )  # Display sample of the data head(patient_data) %>%   kable() %>%   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"),                  full_width = FALSE, position = "center") # Score PGI-I responses pgii_results <- score_pgii(   patient_data = patient_data,   item_name = "pgii_response",   id_column = "patient_id",   keep_n_valid = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE ) #> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:15] Starting PGI-I score calculation #> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:15] Input parameters: item_name = %s, id_column = %s, keep_n_valid = %s, verbose = %s, output_file = %spgii_responsepatient_idTRUETRUENULL #> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:15] Input validation successful #> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:15] Extracted data for %d patients20 #> INFO [2025-03-28 01:20:16] PGI-I scores calculated: %d valid, %d missing200  # Examine results head(pgii_results) %>%   kable() %>%   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"),                  full_width = FALSE, position = "center")

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: score_pgii() function appropriately handles missing data, returning NA original score binary improvement indicator responses missing: Rows missing PGI-responses
code: # Create dataset with missing values patient_data_missing <- patient_data # Set some responses to NA patient_data_missing$pgii_response[c(3, 7, 15)] <- NA  # Score data with missing values pgii_results_missing <- score_pgii(   patient_data = patient_data_missing,   item_name = "pgii_response",   id_column = "patient_id" )  # Examine specifically the rows with missing data pgii_results_missing %>%   filter(is.na(pgii_score)) %>%   kable(caption = "Rows with missing PGI-I responses") %>%   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"),                  full_width = FALSE, position = "center")

code: # Check if device is open before attempting to control it if (!is.null(dev.list())) {   dev.control(displaylist = "enable") }  # Calculate response proportions by treatment group response_profile <- combined_data %>%   group_by(treatment_group, pgii_score) %>%   summarize(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%   group_by(treatment_group) %>%   mutate(     proportion = count / sum(count) * 100,     cumulative = cumsum(proportion),     midpoint = cumulative - proportion/2,     improved = ifelse(pgii_score <= 3, "Improved", "Not Improved")   )  # Create response labels response_labels <- c(   "1" = "Very much better",   "2" = "Much better",   "3" = "A little better",   "4" = "No change",   "5" = "A little worse",   "6" = "Much worse",   "7" = "Very much worse" )  # Create a comprehensive visualization ggplot(response_profile, aes(x = treatment_group, y = proportion, fill = factor(pgii_score))) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack", width = 0.7) +   geom_text(aes(y = midpoint, label = paste0(round(proportion, 1), "%")),             color = "white", fontface = "bold", size = 3.5) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(     option = "D",     labels = response_labels,     guide = guide_legend(title = "PGI-I Response", reverse = FALSE)   ) +   geom_hline(yintercept = 50, linetype = "dashed", color = "white", size = 1) +   annotate("rect", xmin = 0.5, xmax = 2.5, ymin = 0, ymax = 50,             alpha = 0.2, fill = "white") +   labs(     title = "PGI-I Response Profile by Treatment Group",     subtitle = "Distribution of patient-reported improvement outcomes",     x = "Treatment Group",     y = "Proportion of Patients (%)"   ) +   theme(legend.position = "right") +   coord_flip()

title: Scoring the Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20)
text: PFDI-20 consists three subscales: - POPDI-6: Pelvic Organ Prolapse Distress Inventory (6 items) - CRADI-8: Colorectal-Anal Distress Inventory (8 items) - UDI-6: Urinary Distress Inventory (6 items) ensure flexibility, dynamically identify relevant columns:
code: # Select columns starting with "PFDI-" pfdi_cols <- grep("^PFDI-", colnames(pfdi_data), value = TRUE)  # Assign subscale columns popdi_cols <- grep("^PFDI-.*POPDI", pfdi_cols, value = TRUE)  # POPDI-6 cradi_cols <- grep("^PFDI-.*CRADI", pfdi_cols, value = TRUE)  # CRADI-8 udi_cols   <- grep("^PFDI-.*UDI", pfdi_cols, value = TRUE)    # UDI-6  # Verify correct assignment list(POPDI_6 = popdi_cols, CRADI_8 = cradi_cols, UDI_6 = udi_cols)

code: # Create sample PGI-I data pgii_data <- data.frame(   Record_ID = c("PT001", "PT002", "PT003", "PT004", "PT005"),   pgii_response = c(1, 2, 3, 4, NA)  # 1=Very much better, 7=Very much worse )  # Score PGI-I responses pgii_results <- score_pgii(   patient_data = pgii_data,   item_name = "pgii_response",   keep_n_valid = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )  # View results pgii_results #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   Record_ID pgii_score pgii_improved pgii_n_valid #>   <chr>          <dbl>         <dbl>        <int> #> 1 PT001              1             1            4 #> 2 PT002              2             1            4 #> 3 PT003              3             1            4 #> 4 PT004              4             0            4 #> 5 PT005             NA            NA            4

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: urogynScorer provides functions scoring validated patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) used urogynecology clinical practice research. package implements evidence-based scoring algorithms comprehensive validation error handling : Pelvic Organ Prolapse Distress Inventory (POPDI-6) Colorectal-Anal Distress Inventory (CRADI-8) Urinary Distress Inventory (UDI-6) Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-) Sandvik Severity Index urinary incontinence

text: Sandvik index categorizes urinary incontinence severity based frequency amount leakage:
code: # Create sample data sandvik_data <- tibble::tibble(   frequency = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 0),  # 0=Never to 4=Daily   amount = c(1, 2, 3, 2, 1)      # 1=Drops to 3=Large amounts )  # Calculate Sandvik Severity Index sandvik_results <- sandvik_severity_index(   frequency = sandvik_data$frequency,   amount = sandvik_data$amount )  # View results sandvik_results

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: PFDI-20 consists three subscales: - POPDI-6 (questions 1-6): Pelvic Organ Prolapse Distress Inventory - CRADI-8 (questions 7-14): Colorectal-Anal Distress Inventory - UDI-6 (questions 15-20): Urinary Distress Inventory question uses 0-4 scale: - 0: - 1: Somewhat - 2: Moderately - 3: Quite bit - 4: Extremely Scoring process: 1. Calculate mean score subscale (≥50% items answered) 2. Multiply mean 25 get 0-100 scale 3. Sum three subscale scores get PFDI-20 total (0-300 scale)

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: PGI-scored 1-7: 1. much better 2. Much better 3. little better 4. change 5. little worse 6. Much worse 7. much worse score_pgii() function also adds binary improvement indicator (1=improved [1-3], 0=improved [4-7]).

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: index calculated multiplying frequency (0-4) amount (1-3) leakage, resulting : - Slight (≤1) - Moderate (2-5) - Severe (6-9) - Severe (≥10)

title: Calculate PFDI Scores from Minimal Dataset — calculate_pfdi_scores
text: PFDI-20 consists three subscales: POPDI-6 (questions 1-6), CRADI-8 (questions 7-14), UDI-6 (questions 15-20). question uses 0-4 scale. function calculates mean score subscale, multiplies scale factor (default: 25) get 0-100 scale, sums three subscale scores get PFDI-20 total (0-300 scale). function supports multiple column naming conventions including standard format (popdi_q*, cradi_q*, udi_q*), numeric format (PFDI-1 PFDI-20), subscale-specific format (PFDI-POPDI-*, etc.), dot notation (PFDI.1, etc.).

title: urogynScorer: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires — urogynScorer-package
text: comprehensive toolkit scoring, validating, analyzing patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) used urogynecology pelvic floor medicine. package implements standardized scoring algorithms widely-used questionnaires including: Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20) subscales (POPDI-6, CRADI-8, UDI-6), Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-), Sandvik Severity Index urinary incontinence. Core features include: robust validation input data, evidence-based handling missing responses according instrument-specific guidelines, consistent score scaling interpretation, detailed logging quality assurance, comprehensive documentation clinical context. scoring methods follow published validation studies clinical practice guidelines ensure reproducibility research clinical applications.
